text: it may not be obvious when looking at
these prints that they are over a
hundred and sixty years old because they
have a kind of a freshness to them that
that kind of draws you in salt and
silver covers the first two decades of
photography so from 1840 roughly to 1860
even though early American photography
is identified as being mostly
daguerreotype in fact the salt print and
the sort of positive negative process of
it the fact that you can reproduce
multiple prints from a single negative
that's really what's at the core of
photography today you can have an image
that can travel much further than that
one single unique piece of paper could
travel and that was really essential to
the function of photography making it
possible to be in London or in Paris and
yet simultaneously be all around the
world in the way that those empires were
reaching all around the world all of the
prints that are on display in this
exhibition are from a private collection
in London the one exception is we're
showing an album from our collection
here at Yale we call it the Sarah
Annette Jones album it's named after the
young woman who compiled it and we've
included this album and this exhibition
in part to highlight Mary dilwynn
herself so she is probably the most well
known woman photographer who worked with
the salt print process and this album
contains several really remarkable
photographs by Mary Dylan
that work like hers is mounted in albums
is one of the reasons why women
sometimes get left out of the writing of
the history of early photography the
other photographers in this exhibition
who were male you know their work was
produced for a public setting of some
kind like either they were published or
they were being sold or they might have
been exhibited so I think resurrecting
the presence of women in early
photography means taking these albums
seriously and kind of on their own terms
Photography is embedded in everything
that we do it's and our family practices
photojournalism science and one of the
things that makes the the works in this
exhibition I think so important is that
they show the origins of that kind of
embeddedness and the rest of culture and
so when you walk through this exhibition
I hope people can see that photography
is not just part of art it's part of the
history of archaeology it's part of the
history of empire and colonial
governance it's part of the history of
war and journalism about war it's about
all of those histories in there it's
just so much more than art what I want
is for people to come in and experience
the immediacy of these prints and then
reflect upon the ubiquity of photographs
in their own lives and understand that
there's a long rich history to that
if you go back and look at your family
photos from the 30 40 50 years ago
how have they fared they're fading
they're discolored they're probably
stored in plastic sleeves and like a bit
of the emulsion is peeling off I mean
it's like these these prints are they're
so stunning they're in such fine
condition I don't know any other place
where you're going to be able to see
more than 100 salt prints that look like
this in one place I mean it's just
really extraordinary I think that that
will grab people right away it should
